programme.title: Fukushima: 'Nuclear power and humans cannot coexist' | Toll on Argentina's indigenous people
programme.desc: Fukushima: 'Nuclear power and humans cannot coexist' | How fracking is taking its toll on Argentina's indigenous people

programme.title: Plants before pandas | Paradise lost: the town incinerated by California's deadliest wildfire
programme.desc: Plants before pandas: the young botanist tackling extinction in his own backyard | Paradise lost: the town incinerated by California's deadliest wildfire

programme.title: Inside Just Stop Oil: the 'hooligan' climate protesters taking on the tankers
programme.desc: Damien Gayle, a Guardian environment correspondent, follows a group of climate activists as they try to paralyse the UK's fossil fuel distribution network. We film with him as the protesters break into oil terminals, glue themselves to the road, climb onboard oil tankers and let down their tyres. The campaign, called Just Stop Oil, argues the UK has three years to slash its carbon emissions. They have been met with arrests, injunctions and condemnation from politicians – with the government using the Queen’s speech to announce curbs on disruptive protests. But with deep-pocketed supporters, and claims they are signing new volunteers every day, they are vowing to continue.

programme.title: America's soccer migrants: the US footballers crossing Mexico's border
programme.desc: Despite President Donald Trump’s rhetoric about Mexicans crossing the border to the US, American soccer players such as Omar Gonzalez are heading south for new opportunities, more money and a better standard of football. The Guardian travels to Pachuca, Torreón and Guadalajara to speak to top clubs, US immigrant players and Mexico legend Jared Borgetti – who find the prospect of a border wall at odds with the reality of the two nations’ interdependent relationship

programme.title: How Survivors Ink is erasing the marks of the US sex trafficking industry | The Iraqi girls who escaped from Isis
programme.desc: Pimp-led prostitution is one of the most violent and prolific forms of trafficking found in the US, with hundreds of thousands of women sold annually for commercial gain. Many are branded with tattoos by their traffickers as a sign of ownership and control. After experiencing such an ordeal in Columbus, Ohio, Jennifer Kempton founded Survivors Ink, a grassroots project that helps formerly trafficked women to cover up their branding with their own symbols of hope and recovery. | When Isis militants invaded Sinjar in Iraq they took many young Yazidi women and girls – some as young as nine years old – as sexual slaves and forced them to convert to Islam.

programme.title: Inside the mission to create an army of Greta Thunbergs
programme.desc: Melanie Harwood is an education entrepreneur and self-styled 'disruptor', who has partnered with the United Nations to educate teachers about climate change. The Guardian's Richard Sprenger joined her on a trip to Dubai, to witness her unorthodox approach first hand

programme.title: "They're teaching children to hate America": the culture war in US schools
programme.desc: Carmel, Indiana, is an affluent suburb just north of Indianapolis known for low crime rates and some of the country’s best public schools. But early last year, the school board brought in diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives, or DEI, which seek to combat structural racism in the education system. Since then, a battle has erupted between those who welcome the changes, and others who see it as leftwing indoctrination

programme.title: Second innings
programme.desc: From Afghanistan to London, three boys build a new life playing cricket. Tucked away in suburban south London, matches take place every week for young and often traumatised asylum seekers. Many have fled war and have been separated from their families. The Refugee Cricket project, organised by the Refugee Council, provides not only a chance to play and make friends, but also to access advice and support as they navigate the complex asylum system and other challenges in their new home

programme.title: Ticket touting | Inner-city cricket: The West. Fighting for new blood.
programme.desc: Ticket touting | Inner-city cricket: The West. Fighting for new blood.

programme.title: Right to fight: Martial arts fighter with Down's syndrome
programme.desc: Garrett Holeve (aka G Money) has always dreamt of being a Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) fighter, and with the full support of his parents, prepares to fight another disabled opponent. But Florida authorities deemed the contest a health risk. Can G Money win the right to fight and challenge perceptions of what adaptive athletes can do?

programme.title: Fish story
programme.desc: Sometime in the 1980s, Caspar Salmon's grandmother was invited to a gathering on the Welsh island of Anglesey, attended exclusively by people with fish surnames. Or so he says. Thirty years later, film-maker Charlie Lyne attempts to sort myth from reality.

programme.title: Working nights to pack your California strawberries, working days to graduate from school
programme.desc: Ashley Solis is a Mexican American teenager, farmworker and factory worker who dreams of being the first in her family to graduate from high school and go to college. Her mother is undocumented, and like many families with mixed documented status, they face the threat of family separation. With responsibility for earning enough to look after her sisters, Ashley balances working nights in a California strawberry-freezing factory with her school attendance.

programme.title: Little Warrior
programme.desc: Johana Gómez, 10-time and reigning amateur featherweight boxing champion, is determined to pull herself and her family out of extreme poverty in Venezuela. Like Gómez, more than 75% of the Venezuelan population lives below the poverty line due to the ongoing economic crisis there. Through a chance online connection with Scottish boxing trainer Gary Young, locked down in Edinburgh, Gómez's hopes of reaching her potential start to take shape - despite the language barrier.

programme.title: Should robots have faces? | Are computers killing the mystery of chess?
programme.desc: Should robots have faces? | Are computers killing the mystery of chess?

programme.title: Dwarfism and me: 'We're still treated as less than human'
programme.desc: About 90,000 people in America have dwarfism. The writer and podcaster Cara Reedy takes us on a journey to reflect on what it means to be a person with dwarfism – and why America's obsession with little people has left lasting damage.

programme.title: Space to Be: the fight to keep this Belfast women’s centre open
programme.desc: In the heart of the Village, a loyalist area in Belfast, the Windsor Women’s Centre has fought a 30-year battle to keep its doors open. The centre, an oasis for vulnerable women, is deeply rooted in the community. As it faces financial insecurity and navigates the pandemic, will these women make it through their toughest year so far?

programme.title: 'Revenge pornography': Chrissy Chambers' search for justice
programme.desc: In April, it became a crime in England and Wales to post ‘revenge pornography’. Chrissy Chambers and her girlfriend Bria are YouTube’s most popular lesbian content creators. The two channels they run have almost half a million subscribers. But before Chrissy came out, she had a boyfriend. He also has videos of her. And she says he’s using them to destroy her

programme.title: A love letter to Notting Hill Carnival | Inside New York's underground ballroom scene
programme.desc: Notting Hill carnival, held every summer in west London, is the biggest street party in Europe. Coverage of the event often focuses on negative stories and misses the celebration of the community and culture that makes the Carnival so important for London. The Guardian asks carnival veterans why they love it so much, and what keeps them coming back year after year. | The last few years have seen pop culture and fashion take a huge interest in the real scene that inspired TV shows such as Pose and HBO’s Legendary. Can it survive the hype? The Guardian joined the House of Gorgeous Gucci backstage at the Coldest Winter Ball Ever.

programme.title: Run the code: is algorave the future of dance music? | The black art: wet plate collodion photography
programme.desc: Run the code: is algorave the future of dance music? | The black art: wet plate collodion photography

programme.title: Made in Britain
programme.desc: A video journalism project examining poverty, inequality and the challenges our communities face in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.

programme.title: Asking For It | Calling time on street harassment
programme.desc: Asking For It': survivor recounts the day she was raped and her fight for justice | He said: "I’d break the law for you." I was 13': calling time on street harassment

programme.title: The County - what happens after police kill someone you love?
programme.desc: When someone dies after an encounter with law enforcement, he leaves behind parents and children, loss and confusion. What’s to be done when those people sworn to protect you are the same people who pull the trigger?

programme.title: How to fix space's junk problem | Too black for Brazil
programme.desc: No TV, no sat nav, no internet: how to fix space's junk problem | Too black for Brazil

programme.title: Inside Out: Indigenous imprisonment in Australia
programme.desc: Filmed on the plains of north-western New South Wales, this documentary looks at one man's fight against the scourge of Indigenous imprisonment in his community. Inside Out tells the story of a pastor and former prison guard, Uncle Isaac Gordon, whose dream is to see the numbers of Aboriginal youths heading to jail slashed. Gordon wants to build a 'healing centre' for troubled Aboriginal young people at risk of jail time, built on his family's ancestral land near the towns of Brewarrina and Walgett. But will government bodies get on board?

programme.title: Police Brutality: the families left behind | What does it mean to defund the police?
programme.desc: The families left behind after police killings: 'You never get over losing a child' | What does it mean to defund the police?

programme.title: Marielle and Monica: the LGBT activists resisting Bolsonaro's Brazil
programme.desc: The LGBT activists resisting Bolsonaro's Brazil. Marielle Franco, a Brazilian LGBT and human rights activist, was killed in March 2018. Her widow, Monica Benicio, continued her fight for better treatment of the poor, the LGBT community and black Brazilians. The case of her murder has still not been solved and, as the police investigation drifts, Monica is a plunged into a new crisis: the probable election of Jair Bolsonaro.

programme.title: The gym fighting gang violence in east London | How the Covid pandemic has led to more Channel crossings
programme.desc: The gym fighting gang violence in east London: 'Death and trauma shouldn't be normality' | How the Covid pandemic has led to more Channel crossings

programme.title: The island
programme.desc: Christmas Island, off the coast of Australia: here 50 million crabs make their slow and ancient migration from the jungle to the ocean's edge, while thousands of people seeking asylum are indefinitely held in a high security detention facility. Poh Lin, a trauma counsellor living on the island, bears witness to the dramatic stories and decline of those being detained.

programme.title: The quest for the perfect male six-packs | Guantánamo Diary
programme.desc: Steroids, syringes and stigma: the quest for the perfect male six-packs | Guantánamo Diary: rendition, torture and detention without charge

programme.title: Stonewall's Ruth Hunt tells Owen Jones: 'My heart breaks for trans communities' | Transgender life in jail and on the street
programme.desc: The Stonewall chief executive, Ruth Hunt, talks to Owen Jones about her shock at the level of vitriol directed at transgender and non-binary people. | More than one-third of transgender inmates in US jails and prisons report sexual assault. When the San Francisco sheriff announced a plan to implement changes for transgender people in the county jail, film-maker Nick Leader went out to meet the inmates who would benefit.

programme.title: Qandeel
programme.desc: The life, death and impact of Pakistan’s working-class icon Qandeel Baloch, killed in 2016 after becoming a social media celebrity. This film tells Qandeel’s story through her own videos and media appearances. A young, fearless woman who collided with Pakistan’s mainstream media, Qandeel exposed the religious right and challenged middle-class morality.

programme.title: I came out as HIV positive to break down stigma | Staged Sex: Role of the Intimacy Co-Ordinator
programme.desc: Labour MP Lloyd Russell-Moyle came out as HIV positive in a speech in the House of Commons. He tells the Guardian's Owen Jones his diagnosis initially left him feeling like his insides had been ripped out but those fears gradually washed away and he has been able to live his life. He says he hopes his announcement can help break the stigma around HIV and help other people. | The role of the intimacy coordinator has become more important in the wake of the Harvey Weinstein allegations and the broader #MeToo movement. Ita O'Brien works on the set of a short film, Keep Breathing, breaking down the choreography of a sex scene to ensure the wellbeing of the actors and create a clear language...

programme.title: Life in the shadow of Guatemala's Volcano of Fire
programme.desc: On 3 June, the Fuego volcano in Guatemala erupted, killing at least 113 people and leaving 332 missing. Thousands of victims have been displaced and are still living in temporary shelters. Questions are being asked about what the government's disaster prevention agency is doing to help victims. The Guardian journalist Iman Amrani found out how people were coping, and what lessons need to be learned from the disaster

programme.title: Lupita
programme.desc: In a country where indigenous people are increasingly displaced and journalists are killed at an alarming rate, a courageous new voice has emerged: Lupita, a Tzotzil-Maya woman at the forefront of a Mexican indigenous movement. Twenty years after Lupita lost her family in the Acteal massacre in southern Mexico, she has become a spokesperson for her people and for a new generation of Mayan activists.

programme.title: The valley rebels
programme.desc: Cédric Herrou is a farmer who supports and houses African refugees in the alpine village of Breil-Sur-Roya in southern France. Some regard him as a heroic good samaritan, but others – including the French border police and state prosecutor – denounce him as the leader of a band of smugglers, bringing migrants from Italy into France while flouting official border controls. As Cedric moves from one prosecution to another, why do he and his fellow activists feel compelled to defy the authorities?

programme.title: Syrian refugees: the dangerous sea journey to Europe | In troubled waters: the rescue crew saving migrants in the Mediterranean
programme.desc: A Syrian refugee, now settled in Coventry, Britain, describes the hardship of the dangerous Mediterranean crossing that brought her to safety. She and another woman share the dream of being reunited with their families, who are both stuck in Greece. | The Guardian spends five days with the Migrants Offshore Aid Station (MOAS) meetings its crew and the migrants it saved.

programme.title: Teranga: the migrant-run Afrobeat nightclub uniting Naples
programme.desc: Fata and Yankuba are two young Gambians with ambitious dreams, who fled dictatorship and poverty and landed in Naples, only to discover a new kind of violence: a pernicious climate of racism and an unhelpful immigration system. Their only escape from the psychological torture of years spent waiting for documents in squalid camps is a small underground club in the heart of the city. The Teranga nightclub provides a rare safe space for migrants to meet young Italians.

programme.title: Lives Instead of Knives': one woman's struggle to end knife crime
programme.desc: Smith's Farm Estate in Northolt, north-west London, has been the scene of multiple stabbings. After one murder came particularly close to home, community volunteer Jen Lock began a one-woman mission to end knife crime in the area. But, as she finds out, things don’t always go smoothly.

programme.title: My Blonde GF: a disturbing story of deepfake pornography
programme.desc: Helen’s world is turned upside down when she discovers that her face has been digitally edited on to images of women in sexually explicit and often violent situations. Helen shares the impact this deepfake pornography has had on her life and challenges a culture that treats women’s appearance and image as public property while the perpetrators remain anonymous. Deepfake pornography is an increasingly common form of image-based sexual abuse and in June 2023, an amendment of the online safety bill was announced that criminalises the sharing of deepfake intimate images online.

programme.title: The 'Lost Rambos' of Papua New Guinea: how weapons and Hollywood changed tribal disputes
programme.desc: Tribal fighting has long been present in the Papua New Guinea highlands but the influx of modern automatic weaponry in the 1990s turned local disputes into lethal exchanges that threatened to permanently reshape highlands culture. Bootleg copies of the US film Rambo circulated in remote communities, becoming a crude tutorial on the use of such weaponry. The film's influence was so pronounced that the term Rambo is used in Papuan dialects to describe hired mercenaries.

programme.title: Scavengers, miners, and climate activists: can Poland ditch coal?
programme.desc: Poland has a deep and historic relationship with coal, importing huge amounts despite producing yet more locally. With the energy crisis biting, fuelled by the war in Ukraine, the country’s government withdrew restrictions on burning materials and subsidised coal, creating huge air quality issues, particularly in the industrial south – reversing 10 years of hard work by air pollution campaigners in the process.

programme.title: Somali Night Fever
programme.desc: In the 1970s and 80s Mogadishu's airwaves were filled with Somali funk, disco, soul and reggae. Musicians rocking afros and bell-bottom trousers would perform at the city's trendiest nightclubs during the height of the country's golden era of music. But it was short-lived: a brutal civil war began, musicians fled to all corners of the world and the vibrant music scene came to an end.

programme.title: The internet warriors
programme.desc: Who are the people that get so angry online? Meet the internet warriors, in their own homes.

programme.title: The County - what happens after police kill someone you love?
programme.desc: When someone dies after an encounter with law enforcement, he leaves behind parents and children, loss and confusion. What’s to be done when those people sworn to protect you are the same people who pull the trigger?

programme.title: Chalk Girl
programme.desc: Chalk Girl: a protester at the heart of Hong Kong’s democracy movement. Two years since her arrest made her an accidental infamous hero of the pro-democracy umbrella movement, the 16-year-old must decide whether to rejoin the battle alongside the 'localist' youth. As elections loom, Chalk Girl is torn between wanting to respect her family, who are concerned about the risks of her activism, and standing up to Chinese interference.

programme.title: Cancer Town
programme.desc: A year-long series from Reserve, Louisiana, where the risk of cancer is 50 times the national average for the United States. This series of reports will ask what residents have to do to win the right to a safe environment for their children.

programme.title: Guardian Cities: Divided Cities
programme.desc: Divided Cities goes beyond Trump and Brexit to tell the story of five cities that reflect big global divisions in surprising and troubling ways.

programme.title: The Cambridge Analytica Files
programme.sub-title: S01 : E01 The Cambridge Analytica Files
programme.desc: A year-long investigation into Facebook, data, and influencing elections in the digital age.

programme.title: Home match
programme.desc: One crucial year in the life of Alina Shilova, a young Ukrainian woman born and raised in the poor suburbs of Kiev, who is torn between playing football and looking after her family.

programme.title: Can women save sumo? The crossroads facing Japan's national sport
programme.desc: The ancient Japanese sport of sumo is in well-documented crisis. Years of controversy and scandal have hurt the sport's ability to attract new talent. But new energy is brewing in Tokyo's Ryōgoku district, where the sport is slowly adapting to life in the 21st century, and where - despite being banned from the professional ring itself - women are flocking to watch it like never before. Will it be enough to save Japan's national sport in the 21st century?

programme.title: Second innings
programme.desc: From Afghanistan to London, three boys build a new life playing cricket. Tucked away in suburban south London, matches take place every week for young and often traumatised asylum seekers. Many have fled war and have been separated from their families. The Refugee Cricket project, organised by the Refugee Council, provides not only a chance to play and make friends, but also to access advice and support as they navigate the complex asylum system and other challenges in their new home

programme.title: Skip Day - High school friendship and everyday racism in Florida
programme.desc: Intimate glimpses of one very special day in the lives of high-school seniors from an industrial corner of the Florida Everglades: prom’s over, the future is uncertain, and the irresistible pull of the beach makes the long-time friends drive 60 miles to chill, pose and revel in the waves. Once at the beach, friendship, discussions about what's next, and an unwelcome dose of everyday racism mix. Winner of the Illy Prize for best short film at Directors’ Fortnight, Cannes Film Festival.

programme.title: The Living Forest | Our Iranian lockdown
programme.desc: The Living Forest | Our Iranian lockdown: how coronavirus changed one couple’s life

programme.title: The Winterkeeper: a lifetime spent protecting the wilderness
programme.desc: Steven Fuller is a winter caretaker who has lived at Yellowstone national park for the past 50 years. As the cold weather approaches and the seasonal transformation begins, he hunkers down in his remote mountain cabin. But Fuller and Yellowstone face an uncertain future, with the climate crisis threatening to change one of North America’s last great wildernesses for ever.

programme.title: Cinema of Ukraine: artists reflect on modern history, culture and people
programme.desc: Presented in collaboration with the Kyiv-based Docudays UA film festival, these award-winning movies offer insight into the modern history of the country, its culture and its people. In This Rain Will Never Stop, directed by Alina Gorlova, we meet 20-year-old Andriy Suleyman, who escaped Syria with his family and found refuge in Ukraine, his mother’s homeland. Shot in striking black and white, the film is a sophisticated vision of war zones and the scars they leave.

programme.title: Radical Brownies
programme.desc: Berets, badges, Black Lives Matter and social justice: the youth group for activist girls of colour.

programme.title: Skyward: birdwatching is belonging for two teenage conservationists
programme.desc: Young birdwatchers Mya and Arjun feel the pressure of climate breakdown and the biodiversity crisis. As two reserved teenagers on the cusp of adulthood, they find comfort in birdwatching while being distant from their peers. Fascinated by migratory patterns, Mya spends her time searching for rare bird species, while Arjun is captivated by the beauty of birdsong. As their passion for nature inspires them to raise awareness of conservation and the climate emergency in their communities, they find themselves and their voices, emerging as local leaders among a new generation of conservationists.

programme.title: Run the code: is algorave the future of dance music? | The black art: wet plate collodion photography
programme.desc: Run the code: is algorave the future of dance music? | The black art: wet plate collodion photography

programme.title: No ball games: life and play through the eyes of children across the UK
programme.desc: Celebrating the imagination and resourcefulness of young children across the UK by understanding the outdoor games they invent, inherit and play. The documentary was shot before Covid-19 changed their lives, and shifts from rural Wales to post-industrial Teesside and inner-city London. What challenges will these young people face in the aftermath of brutal funding cuts to youth services? How can their optimistic energy strengthen their resilience in these challenging times?

programme.title: Inside Out: Indigenous imprisonment in Australia
programme.desc: Filmed on the plains of north-western New South Wales, this documentary looks at one man's fight against the scourge of Indigenous imprisonment in his community. Inside Out tells the story of a pastor and former prison guard, Uncle Isaac Gordon, whose dream is to see the numbers of Aboriginal youths heading to jail slashed. Gordon wants to build a 'healing centre' for troubled Aboriginal young people at risk of jail time, built on his family's ancestral land near the towns of Brewarrina and Walgett. But will government bodies get on board?

programme.title: Malcolm Gladwell in conversation with Ben Fountain
programme.desc: The two writers sat down in Brooklyn, New York, to talk about Fountain's new book Beautiful Country Burn Again and Trump, Hillary Clinton and the American psyche

programme.title: The ASMR videos that give YouTube viewers 'head orgasms' | Psychology of queues and how to beat them
programme.desc: The ASMR videos that give YouTube viewers 'head orgasms' | After you: the psychology of queues and how to beat them

programme.title: Silent Sam
programme.desc: Sam is a 27-year-old music-teaching, sovereign ring-wearing, chanting Buddhist. He is the lead singer of an up-and-coming punk band - but he’s also mute... at least for most of the time. After two unsuccessful vocal chord operations, Sam spends most of his time in pain and on voice rest. Yet, by communicating silently through writing notes, mouthing words and blowing kisses (one for yes and two for no), he still somehow manages to be the chattiest person in the room.

programme.title: Untold Chaos: Living through Libya's wars
programme.desc: At the end of his US presidency, Barack Obama said his worst mistake was failing to plan for the day after the intervention in Libya. What followed was chaos. Filmed over seven years, this is an observational mosaic, capturing the feeling of a country in the hands of warlords and a proxy war, while a divided political process and a fragile international peace deal loom.

programme.title: Sprinter Factory
programme.desc: These are the girls running as fast as they can to be Jamaica’s new sprint champions in a country obsessed with its athletes. This is the story of the Champs national youth athletics competition that could change their lives.

programme.title: A Childhood on Fire
programme.desc: When Nick Hurndon was six years old he and his two older brothers were set on fire by their stepfather in their San Francisco home. Now in his early forties, Nick is a retired Marine and is raising two sons that are about the same age he was when he was set ablaze. This is a film about childhood trauma and the effects that abuse had on his sense of self worth, and the ways in which one man is interrupting a cycle of violence so that his two sons can thrive

programme.title: Muhammad Ali | Sucker punch: small town boxing in rural America
programme.desc: Guardian boxing correspondent Kevin Mitchell and columnist Gary Younge reflect back on the life and career of the self-proclaimed greatest boxer of all time, Muhammad Ali. | Rough N Rowdy offers local hopefuls, most with limited skills and little training, the chance to win $1,000 and make a name for themselves in the boxing ring.

programme.title: Quipu: Calls for Justice
programme.desc: Esperanza and Teodula are calling for justice in rural Peru, part of 300,000 people sterilised without consent more than 18 years ago. The Quipu Project is their phoneline that allows victims across the country to share their shocking testimonies and ensure those responsible are punished.

programme.title: The Tower next door
programme.desc: In June 2017 residents of the Silchester estate woke to discover Grenfell Tower engulfed in flames, witnessing a terrifying national tragedy unfolding on their doorstep. The tower bore a striking resemblance to their own. The victims were people they knew, people from all walks of life who, like them, made a home for themselves high up above the clamour of the city. Faced with an uncertain future, the residents of the tower next door are fighting to rebuild their community.

programme.title: The Fight
programme.desc: People with disabilities are among the most discriminated against in Bolivia. Fed up with being ignored, a group of them march across the Andes to the seat of the government in La Paz, asking to speak to President Evo Morales. They are met with riot police, barricades, teargas and water cannon.

programme.title: Women smash Catholic taboos in the Philippines | Fake babies, real love | Crisanto Street
programme.desc: At 11 years old, they're getting pregnant: women smash Catholic taboos in the Philippines | Fake babies, real love: the women who care for lifelike baby dolls | Crisanto Street

programme.title: On the road
programme.desc: Hundreds of women operate as sex workers along the Strada Bonifica, the ironically named ‘road of love’ on the Adriatic coast of Italy. There has been a huge increase in the number of Nigerian women working along the 10-mile stretch of road – some of whom have been trafficked into the country and forced into prostitution. The film moves between the women’s stories, the Italians who live and work there and the local NGO, named On the Road, attempting to support the women

programme.title: Fighting Shame
programme.desc: A group of women use everyday items to tell of the sacrifices and difficult choices they face, and the community initiatives they have launched in an attempt to tackle the shame surrounding poverty and make policymakers listen.

programme.title: On the Ground
programme.desc: In-depth Guardian video journalism from around the world.

programme.title: The imams, the Taliban and the condom | The Black Panthers still in prison after 46 years, will they ever be set free?
programme.desc: The imams, the Taliban and the condom | The Black Panthers still in prison after 46 years, will they ever be set free?

programme.title: Meet the people fighting to keep Ireland's abortion ban | Peterloo: A massacre that changed Britain
programme.desc: Meet the people fighting to keep Ireland's abortion ban | A massacre that changed Britain: does Peterloo still resonate today?

programme.title: Can Yanis Varoufakis save Europe?
programme.desc: The Greek economist is back battling the EU establishment, this time at the helm of a new movement, DiEM25. Backed by Pamela Anderson and the world’s most famous cyborg, he is fighting ultra-right populism with a radical agenda he thinks can restore people's lost faith in democracy. As the European parliamentary elections approach, is anyone listening? Phoebe Greenwood finds out

programme.title: How to make a pearl
programme.desc: For 53 years, John Kapellas enjoyed the bright sky of the western US, but one day he started to burn, blister and break out in rashes whenever he was exposed to light. Now allergic to the entire spectrum of light, Kapellas has spent the last decade living in complete darkness. When one of the side effects of the drugs John was prescribed made him ‘go nuts’, he started drawing large abstract pictures on his walls and playing the piano to calm his mind and soothe the pain.

programme.title: The Wolf Dividing Norway
programme.desc: With unique access to remote communities in the snow-capped landscape of Norway, this film follows characters on either side of a fierce debate on whether to cull the wolf population. For decades the topic has split political parties, families and communities across the country, with environmentalists world-wide criticising Norway for how it handles its tiny population of critically endangered wolves. .

programme.title: Dear Bradford: a love letter to a misunderstood city
programme.desc: From Muslim ‘no-go areas’ to Brexit-voting white nationalists, stereotypes continue to be perpetuated about Bradford 21 years after the 'race riots'. Farhaan was born in the city in the 1980s to a family of south Asian Muslim heritage. From a young age he feared being ‘found out’ and lived a dual existence, moving away from Bradford as soon as he could. He spent years travelling the world and teaching English. But, when the coronavirus pandemic hit, Farhaan was reluctantly forced to return to his hometown. Through his beloved grandma, or 'Amma', and the poetry of his late grandfather, Farhaan learned how to love Bradford – and himself.

programme.title: Ghosts of Moria: living in the ashes of Europe's largest migrant camp
programme.desc: As Europe’s most infamous migrant camp burned to the ground on the island of Lesbos in 2020, two Syrian friends evaded police to stay. Living in a post-apocalyptic graveyard, Ayham and Khalil now race against local scrap metal collectors to find what they can, which they are forced to sell at a reduced price. With what little money they make they buy food and cook together, dreaming of Aleppo before the civil war forced them to leave and waiting for an end to their bureaucratic limbo. From their shared tent their friendship endures, despite their impossible circumstances.

programme.title: The Breadmaker: Venezuelan activists fighting to feed a community
programme.desc: Natalia Molina and other members of La Minka, a Chavista collective, run a revolutionary bakery in the Venezuelan capital. They have been occupying the shop in Caracas since March 2017 in an attempt to provide their local community with affordable food.

programme.title: Behind the scenes on Birmingham derby day with football fans and police
programme.desc: Police on the streets separating rival supporters, cordons restricting access around the ground, holding the away end back after full time: these are familiar experiences for football fans attending derbies up and down the country. Here we go behind the scenes at Birmingham City v Aston Villa to explore how police and fans interact with each other on match day

programme.title: Globalised slavery: how big supermarkets are selling prawns in supply chain fed by slave labour
programme.desc: A six-month Guardian multimedia investigation has, for the first time, tracked how some of the world's big-supermakets, Tesco, Aldi, Walmart and Morrisons, are using suppliers relying on slave labour to put cheap prawns on their shelves. Slavery is back and here's the proof. Narrated by Benedict Cumberbatch.

programme.title: Finding Ashley | Murder, corruption and cattle barons in Kenya
programme.desc: Finding Ashley: a Native American family's desperate search for their missing relative | Murder, corruption and cattle barons in Kenya

programme.title: Dallas Detective agency | Why journalists carry guns in the Philippines
programme.desc: Dallas Detective agency | Why journalists carry guns in the Philippines

programme.title: Share
programme.desc: Tim Chau is an 18-year-old Asian-American with more than 4m followers on Instagram. He lives online, grabbing his phone first thing in the morning and even taking baths with it sometimes. Although Tim usually shares funny memes, he occasionally posts about mental health. In exploring his reasons for these posts, we discover he has created a different persona online than in real life.

programme.title: Someone Else's War
programme.desc: To date at least 20 British nationals, some with no previous experience of combat, have travelled to Syria to fight Isis on the frontline. Eight of these Brits have lost their lives. This film follows the journeys of parents as they investigate why their children went to join the Kurdish army in their fight against Isis. What led these young Brits to risk everything, travelling thousands of miles from home to wage war against the world’s most feared terrorist organisation?

programme.title: How Survivors Ink is erasing the marks of the US sex trafficking industry | The Iraqi girls who escaped from Isis
programme.desc: Pimp-led prostitution is one of the most violent and prolific forms of trafficking found in the US, with hundreds of thousands of women sold annually for commercial gain. Many are branded with tattoos by their traffickers as a sign of ownership and control. After experiencing such an ordeal in Columbus, Ohio, Jennifer Kempton founded Survivors Ink, a grassroots project that helps formerly trafficked women to cover up their branding with their own symbols of hope and recovery. | When Isis militants invaded Sinjar in Iraq they took many young Yazidi women and girls – some as young as nine years old – as sexual slaves and forced them to convert to Islam.

programme.title: The foreign domestic staff living a life of five-star serfdom in London | Isis has my kids
programme.desc: I was just a slave: the foreign domestic staff living a life of five-star serfdom in London | Isis has my kids: I won't stop till I get them home to the US

programme.title: From California gang to Mexican vigilante | The final interview with a legendary journalist
programme.desc: From California gang to Mexican vigilante: the family man fighting the drug cartels in Mexico | Murdered in Mexico: the final interview with a legendary journalist

programme.title: He died sitting on our front porch: the fight to stop Chicago's gang killings
programme.desc: Over the Fourth of July weekend, over 100 people were shot in Chicago – a worrying increase after the city’s murder rate had fallen to its lowest level in 40 years. Adam Gabbatt visits the city’s south side to understand why gang violence remains such a problem – and how grassroots groups are working to prevent it

programme.title: Italian mafia’s cocaine trafficking leaves trail of drug devastation among poor of Brazil
programme.desc: The all-powerful Calabrian crime syndicate 'Ndrangheta has forged a deadly network of drug trafficking routes through Brazil – 80% of all cocaine arriving in Europe comes through the country's Santos port. To mark International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking, we hear from the anti-'Ndrangheta experts risking their lives to speak out against the syndicate, and take to the streets of Brazil's Crackolândia districts, where crack addiction is destroying lives.

programme.title: World Cup Slaves
programme.desc: Nepalese men employed in Qatar's construction industry tell Robert Booth how they work for little or no pay as they build the infrastructure ahead of the 2022 football World Cup. Appalling living conditions and unsafe employment are not the only difficulties they face: there is pressure and disbelief from families in Nepal when no money is sent back home

programme.title: RIP SENI: racism, graffiti and the UK's mental health crisis
programme.desc: One morning in June 2020, graffiti reading RIP SENI appeared emblazoned across a public artwork outside the Bethlem royal hospital, a psychiatric hospital in south London. The spray-painted letters drew attention to Olaseni Lewis, a 23-year-old black man who died after being restrained by 11 police officers while in the care of the hospital in 2010. This film follows what happened after the graffiti, as it launches a discussion about race, mental health and injustice in the UK, and the effects on families.

programme.title: Untold Chaos: Living through Libya's wars
programme.desc: At the end of his US presidency, Barack Obama said his worst mistake was failing to plan for the day after the intervention in Libya. What followed was chaos. Filmed over seven years, this is an observational mosaic, capturing the feeling of a country in the hands of warlords and a proxy war, while a divided political process and a fragile international peace deal loom.

programme.title: The golden poison dart frog | If you eat beef, don't wash
programme.desc: The golden poison dart frog: 'Like holding a loaded gun' | The solution to California's drought: if you eat beef, don't wash

programme.title: Dearborn, Michigan
programme.desc: In the last 12 months the city of Dearborn, Michigan, has been thrown into conflict. At its heart, the conflict is about fear, ideology and identity politics – and what it means to be an American. Dearborn, home to the largest mosque in North America, is a place of apparent contradictions: simultaneously a sleepy, affluent suburb and yet also the subject of rumours about Isis terror cells and sharia law.

programme.title: The Syrian spaceman who became a refugee | Netflix fans uncover the real life of Pablo Escobar
programme.desc: The Syrian spaceman who became a refugee | Narcotours: Netflix fans uncover the real life of Pablo Escobar

programme.title: Made in Britain
programme.desc: A video journalism project examining poverty, inequality and the challenges our communities face in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.

programme.title: Sprinter Factory
programme.desc: These are the girls running as fast as they can to be Jamaica’s new sprint champions in a country obsessed with its athletes. This is the story of the Champs national youth athletics competition that could change their lives.

programme.title: Blood, sweat and fears: special report on abuse towards grassroots football referees
programme.desc: The FA has rebooted its Respect Campaign this season to protect grassroots referees in England but many continue to suffer both mental and physical abuse. There are some horrifying stories but hope remains: as of 2019-20 season a new sin-bin system will be rolled out across all grassroots leagues for anybody caught abusing a referee, with other initiatives also in the pipeline.

programme.title: Leonora Carrington: Britain's lost surrealist | Rembrandt's portraits at the National Gallery
programme.desc: Leonora Carrington escaped a stultifying Lancashire childhood to run off with Max Ernst and hang out with Picasso and André Breton in 1930s Paris. She fled the Nazis, escaped from a psychiatric hospital in Spain and became a national treasure in Mexico. What happened to one of Britain's finest - and neglected - surrealists? | A revealing look at Rembrandt's most intimate portraits, on display in the locked-down National Gallery in London.

programme.title: La caravana: On the road with the migrant caravan
programme.desc: Thousands of migrants from Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala head north hoping to find work and a better life in the US. The largest Central American caravan in decades keeps growing as thousands more join this journey – but when they reach Mexico, the migrant caravan starts taking different directions.

programme.title: Colette
programme.desc: 90-year-old Colette Marin-Catherine confronts her past by visiting the German concentration camp Mittelbau-Dora where her brother was killed. As a young girl, she fought Hitler's Nazis as a member of the French Resistance. For 74 years, she has refused to step foot in Germany, but that changes when a young history student named Lucie enters her life. Prepared to re-open old wounds and revisit the terrors of that time, Marin-Catherine offers important lessons for us all.

programme.title: The 'Lost Rambos' of Papua New Guinea: how weapons and Hollywood changed tribal disputes
programme.desc: Tribal fighting has long been present in the Papua New Guinea highlands but the influx of modern automatic weaponry in the 1990s turned local disputes into lethal exchanges that threatened to permanently reshape highlands culture. Bootleg copies of the US film Rambo circulated in remote communities, becoming a crude tutorial on the use of such weaponry. The film's influence was so pronounced that the term Rambo is used in Papuan dialects to describe hired mercenaries.

programme.title: Fish story
programme.desc: Sometime in the 1980s, Caspar Salmon's grandmother was invited to a gathering on the Welsh island of Anglesey, attended exclusively by people with fish surnames. Or so he says. Thirty years later, film-maker Charlie Lyne attempts to sort myth from reality.

programme.title: The Climate and the Cross
programme.desc: An internal battle is simmering among US Christians over whether climate change is a call to protect the Earth, the work of God to be welcomed, or does not exist at all.

programme.title: Where the River Runs Red - a mining community caught between the past and a sustainable future
programme.desc: In the isolated west of Tasmania an ominous red river divides the small mining town of Queenstown. A result of copper run-off from a closed mine, it is an ever-present reminder of the town’s history of environmental and industrial disaster. Where the River Runs Red explores a community in an economically crippled area caught between the past and a future that is less reliant on a mining economy.

programme.title: Is this inclusive? Why only 4% of children's book heroes are BAME
programme.desc: More than 33% of students at UK schools are from black and minority ethnic backgrounds, but only 4% of the protagonists in children's books in the UK are BAME. The publishing industry has made big claims about its push for inclusivity both on and off the page, but some believe progress is painfully slow. Grace Shutti investigates what’s taking UK publishing so long and meets some of the creators who are championing change, including the authors of hit books Amazing Grace and Look Up!, and the owners of inclusive publisher Round Table books.

programme.title: Sam and the Plant Next Door
programme.desc: Sam, 11, is always being told not to worry about the nuclear power plant rising next door, but for him there is lots to think about. Hinkley Point C will be Britain’s largest nuclear plant, and it’s only two miles away. Most of his classmates expect to work at the plant but Sam is determined to escape that fate. His dream is to protect the surrounding marine life he identifies with. Like the fish, he feels unappreciated by the adults.

programme.title: Muxes
programme.desc: In Juchitán, Mexico, muxes – children identified as male at birth, but who choose at a young age to be raised as female – are embraced as part of the community.

programme.title: 'Revenge pornography': Chrissy Chambers' search for justice
programme.desc: In April, it became a crime in England and Wales to post ‘revenge pornography’. Chrissy Chambers and her girlfriend Bria are YouTube’s most popular lesbian content creators. The two channels they run have almost half a million subscribers. But before Chrissy came out, she had a boyfriend. He also has videos of her. And she says he’s using them to destroy her

programme.title: If you're only dating someone for their skin colour, you should consider why | Conectifai
programme.desc: Swipe my race: 'If you're only dating someone for their skin colour, you should consider why' | Conectifai

programme.title: YouTube kids: how unboxing, gaming and toy reviews took over
programme.desc: Being a YouTuber is now the most popular aspiration for children today, according to a survey. In 2018, the site’s highest earner was a seven-year-old American toy reviewer. But the video platform has been mired in controversy over its failure to protect children. Richard Sprenger meets some of the children plying their trade on YouTube, viral sensation Rebecca Black, and visits a Los Angeles summer camp where kids as young as six learn the tricks of the trade

programme.title: We Walk Together
programme.desc: Thousands of refugees were sleeping rough at Budapest’s Keleti station, waiting for trains to take them to western Europe. Then, they just got up and walked. Guardian journalist and filmmaker John Domokos went with them, every step of the way. This is the story of one Syrian family, and those who came out to help

programme.title: Stonewall's Ruth Hunt tells Owen Jones: 'My heart breaks for trans communities' | Transgender life in jail and on the street
programme.desc: The Stonewall chief executive, Ruth Hunt, talks to Owen Jones about her shock at the level of vitriol directed at transgender and non-binary people. | More than one-third of transgender inmates in US jails and prisons report sexual assault. When the San Francisco sheriff announced a plan to implement changes for transgender people in the county jail, film-maker Nick Leader went out to meet the inmates who would benefit.

programme.title: Dwarfism and me: 'We're still treated as less than human'
programme.desc: About 90,000 people in America have dwarfism. The writer and podcaster Cara Reedy takes us on a journey to reflect on what it means to be a person with dwarfism – and why America's obsession with little people has left lasting damage.

programme.title: Home match
programme.desc: One crucial year in the life of Alina Shilova, a young Ukrainian woman born and raised in the poor suburbs of Kiev, who is torn between playing football and looking after her family.

programme.title: Gay, black and HIV positive: America's hidden epidemic
programme.desc: If you are a black, gay man in America, your risk of contracting HIV is one in two. Leah Green travels to Atlanta, Georgia, which has the largest gay and black community in the country. She finds out how stigma, education and structural racism continue to feed into this startling statistic

programme.title: Qandeel
programme.desc: The life, death and impact of Pakistan’s working-class icon Qandeel Baloch, killed in 2016 after becoming a social media celebrity. This film tells Qandeel’s story through her own videos and media appearances. A young, fearless woman who collided with Pakistan’s mainstream media, Qandeel exposed the religious right and challenged middle-class morality.

programme.title: The only way out is through Jesus: The El Salvador pastors saving MS-13 gang members
programme.desc: In El Salvador, where brutal gangs like MS-13 and 18th Street have given the country the world’s highest murder rate, the only way out for members is to become born-again Christians. In this intimate look at the lives of former gang members, we follow two pastors from the rival gangs as they convert gang members to stop them falling back into violent ways

programme.title: The Night Wolves: Putin's motorbiking militia of Luhansk
programme.desc: Production Year: 2016. The Night Wolves are Russia’s largest and most notorious biker gang, fiercely loyal to Vladimir Putin, and say they are motivated by Christianity and patriotism. Their base in Luhansk, east Ukraine, resembles a set from Mad Max. Inside their stronghold, the Night Wolves open up about the families they left behind.

programme.title: Somali Night Fever
programme.desc: In the 1970s and 80s Mogadishu's airwaves were filled with Somali funk, disco, soul and reggae. Musicians rocking afros and bell-bottom trousers would perform at the city's trendiest nightclubs during the height of the country's golden era of music. But it was short-lived: a brutal civil war began, musicians fled to all corners of the world and the vibrant music scene came to an end.

programme.title: Silent Sam
programme.desc: Sam is a 27-year-old music-teaching, sovereign ring-wearing, chanting Buddhist. He is the lead singer of an up-and-coming punk band - but he’s also mute... at least for most of the time. After two unsuccessful vocal chord operations, Sam spends most of his time in pain and on voice rest. Yet, by communicating silently through writing notes, mouthing words and blowing kisses (one for yes and two for no), he still somehow manages to be the chattiest person in the room.

programme.title: Happy birthday
programme.desc: For years, global music publisher Warner/Chappell claimed copyright of the Happy Birthday song, demanding payment for any public performance of it. Jenn Nelson tells the story of her four-year campaign to prove that the company did not in fact own the rights to the world-famous song, whose tune was composed by two sisters in Kentucky in 1893. A judge’s decision on 30 June to approve a $14m settlement means the song is now in the public domain

programme.title: The Hour of Lynching - vigilante violence in India
programme.desc: Rakbar, a Muslim dairy farmer, was murdered by a Hindu mob who thought he was taking a cow to be slaughtered for meat. His wife, Asmeena, must undergo an intense iddat (mourning in purdah) and their daughter, Sahila, is forced to abandon school to take care of the household. While the family falls apart, the hate machinery of rightwing Hindu nationalists – politicians and lynch mobs – works overtime to legitimise the killing.

programme.title: On the Ground
programme.desc: In-depth Guardian video journalism from around the world.

programme.title: America's Dirty Divide
programme.desc: A series examining the country's vast environmental inequalities and how climate change will make things worse.

programme.title: The Waiting Room
programme.desc: When Victoria Mapplebeck was diagnosed with breast cancer, she decided to record each step of her journey. Shot on an iPhone X, Mapplebeck filmed her time in waiting rooms, surgery and chemotherapy. The Waiting Room is an unflinching portrait of the blood, sweat and tears of cancer treatment. At home Mapplebeck filmed with her teenage son, as they came to terms with how family life was transformed by a year of living with cancer.

programme.title: Beirut Dreams in Color
programme.desc: Mashrou’ Leila were one of the biggest bands in the Middle East, with a lead singer, Hamed, who is the most prominent openly gay rock star in the Arab world. Known globally, their gigs were regular sell-out successes until an event at their 2017 Cairo concert changed everything. Playing to 35,000 people, the band looked out at a sea of swaying flickering lights, including an Egyptian fan flying a rainbow flag. This simple act would later be described by authorities as ‘inciting debauchery’, and ultimately catapulted the band, the fan and others into a tragic series of events.

programme.title: Love Jihad: India's lethal religious conspiracy theory
programme.desc: The mutilated body of a 24-year-old Muslim, Arbaaz Aftab Mullah, was discovered on a railway track near his home. His family believe he was murdered because of his interfaith relationship with a Hindu woman and that he is one of the latest victims of the 'love jihad' conspiracy theory, which has swept across groups of Hindu nationalists in India. The theory claims that Muslim men are seducing Hindu women and luring them into marriage in order to convert them to Islam.

programme.title: The Fight
programme.desc: People with disabilities are among the most discriminated against in Bolivia. Fed up with being ignored, a group of them march across the Andes to the seat of the government in La Paz, asking to speak to President Evo Morales. They are met with riot police, barricades, teargas and water cannon.

programme.title: Somalinimo
programme.desc: As students return to universities around the world, four British-Somali students talk about navigating one of Britain’s most elite institutions: Cambridge University. Their identity is rooted in Somalinimo (‘the essence of being Somali’) and in this love letter to Somali culture, blackness and Islam, they reflect on both belonging and marginalisation.

programme.title: Space to Be: the fight to keep this Belfast women’s centre open
programme.desc: In the heart of the Village, a loyalist area in Belfast, the Windsor Women’s Centre has fought a 30-year battle to keep its doors open. The centre, an oasis for vulnerable women, is deeply rooted in the community. As it faces financial insecurity and navigates the pandemic, will these women make it through their toughest year so far?

programme.title: Why is Vladimir Putin so obsessed with Ukraine? I count myself as a Black Ukrainian
programme.desc: Guardian correspondent Luke Harding chronicles the key historical events that led to the invasion of Ukraine, from the Euromaidan protests to the annexation of Crimea, and explains why Putin's belief that Russians and Ukrainians are 'one people' is rooted in history from a thousand years ago. | Welcome to the refugee lifestyle,' says Eno Enyieokpon, who is re-establishing his brand, Enno, in Budapest having left everything behind in Kyiv. Identifying as a black Ukrainian, Eno says most of the ideas that have changed his life as a designer have come from tough times in Ukraine.

programme.title: The Native American kids who get $200k for graduating
programme.desc: The Ho-Chunk Nation are a Native American tribe that owns a string of casinos across Wisconsin. Ho Chunk children get a share of casino profits once they’ve graduated and turned 18. It’s called their 18 Money. When they finish high school, they get given $200,000. Journalist and film-maker Jenny Kleeman meets the Ho Chunk kids of Black River Falls high school and their families as they graduate, along with tribal representatives and residents of Black River Falls, Wisconsin.

programme.title: 'Revenge pornography': Chrissy Chambers' search for justice
programme.desc: In April, it became a crime in England and Wales to post ‘revenge pornography’. Chrissy Chambers and her girlfriend Bria are YouTube’s most popular lesbian content creators. The two channels they run have almost half a million subscribers. But before Chrissy came out, she had a boyfriend. He also has videos of her. And she says he’s using them to destroy her

programme.title: On the road
programme.desc: Hundreds of women operate as sex workers along the Strada Bonifica, the ironically named ‘road of love’ on the Adriatic coast of Italy. There has been a huge increase in the number of Nigerian women working along the 10-mile stretch of road – some of whom have been trafficked into the country and forced into prostitution. The film moves between the women’s stories, the Italians who live and work there and the local NGO, named On the Road, attempting to support the women

programme.title: The Observers
programme.desc: A show produced with photos, videos and personal accounts from our Observers around the world all checked by our staff here in Paris.

programme.title: Ona Carbonell: Começar de novo
programme.desc: Em agosto de 2020, a nadadora artística olímpica Ona Carbonell tornou-se mãe, uma experiência que mudou de imediato a sua vida. Ao mesmo tempo, Ona embarcou num plano ambicioso para competir nos Jogos Olímpicos de Tóquio. O documentário acompanha Ona durante estes 11 meses intensos, em que terá de forçar os seus limites a um grau extraordinário, tanto física como emocionalmente. Acompanhamos Ona de perto, partilhando as suas rotinas e desafios diários, desde a amamentação aos momentos de brincadeira com o bebé Kai, passando pelas sessões de treino intenso com a Seleção Nacional Espanhola.

programme.title: Give Up Tomorrow
programme.desc: Nas Filipinas, um homem inocente enfrenta a pena de morte num polêmico caso de assassinato que separou duas famílias e uma nação inteira.

programme.title: We All Play
programme.desc: “WE ALL PLAY” é um projeto que explora a realidade da comunidade LGBTQIA+ no mundo do desporto. Através de uma viagem à volta do mundo, este documentário inspirador apresenta-nos atletas de elite extraordinários que, muitas vezes pela primeira vez, partilham as suas experiências pessoais e profissionais. Os seus testemunhos revelam visões diferentes e opiniões profundas sobre os triunfos e os desafios diários enfrentados por estes atletas. Dando ênfase à importância da inclusão e da aceitação, o documentário evidencia como o desporto pode constituir um espaço para a diversidade e o respeito, promovendo uma mudança positiva em todas as áreas do desporto e para além dele.

programme.title: Fast Forward - Episode 1 - 5
programme.desc: Fusão Nuclear | Corpos Biónicos | Limpadores do Espaço | Carne Criada em Laboratório | Blockchain, protocolo da confiança

programme.title: Episódios 7-8
programme.desc: A Tormenta de 18 Dias | Um Novo Começo

programme.title: HairStyle, The Talent Show -Episódios 1 - 2
programme.desc: No primeiro episódio, para se apresentarem aos jurados, os participantes usam a sua capacidade de engenho para criar um visual livre e solto. O único limite é a sua capacidade criativa. Também serão avaliados quanto a cinco técnicas de cabeleireiro essenciais; o último classificado será eliminado. A celebridade televisiva e influencer de moda Tina Leung irá visitar o salão para revelar a sua rotina de cuidado capilar e oferecer algumas dicas valiosas.

programme.title: Karate-do: O Caminho de Sandra Sánchez
programme.desc: Não é um dragão, mas parece no dojo. Eis Sandra Sánchez, uma das maiores figuras do karate de sempre. Esta é a história do seu percurso único. Dos seus feitos. Uma história complicada que inclui a prática do karate em criança, uma relação abusiva na vida adulta e um penúltimo ano de carreira inacreditável onde que bateu recordes ao competir nos três mais prestigiosos campeonatos de karate – e vencê-los. O caminho até ao sucesso nunca é fácil, mas nos Jogos Olímpicos de Tóquio, Sandra lutou por e contra muitas dificuldades para conquistar um lugar nos anais da história.

programme.title: Paradiso
programme.desc: Rafael é o projecionista do último cinema de filmes pornográficos de Madrid. Está convicto de que todos os dias pode fazer um melhor trabalho.

programme.title: Break Through
programme.desc: Uma peça encenada por estudantes de teatro torna-se num espetáculo subversivo em prol dos direitos LGBT.

programme.title: Brother's Body
programme.desc: Quando decide (voltar a) mergulhar no mundo do culturismo, David Nicolas Parel ambiciona seguir nas pisadas do seu irmão mais novo e treinar para o Arnold Classic – uma competição que deve o nome ao célebre ator e político austríaco-americano.

programme.title: Make Up Stars - T1: Cor - Futuro
programme.desc: Os toucadores do Makeup Stars são tomados pela cor, com os concorrentes a enfrentar o primeiro desafio com a técnica de caracterização. Seguirão as instruções da maquilhadora Anna Cartés, especialista na técnica das perucas e em apagar as feições dos modelos para criar novas personagens. Agoney, um cantor camaleónico e fã da maquilhagem, visitará o programa para dar conselhos aos concorrentes. Quem será a ""Super Estrela"" e ganhará privilégios para o próximo episódio? Quem terá a pontuação mais baixa? Não percas uma explosão de cor.

programme.title: Rumeysa: De cabeça erguida
programme.desc: Com 2,15 m de altura, a impressionante estatura de Rumeysa Gelgi é apenas comparável à sua assombrosa força interior. Rumeysa Gelgi nasceu com uma mutação genética rara, a síndrome de Weaver. E a vida não tem sido fácil para a mulher mais alta do mundo. Agora, graças a uma cirurgia que lhe mudou a vida, está pronta a viajar pela primeira vez aos EUA para conhecer algumas das mulheres mais inspiradoras do mundo. Na sua viagem de autodescoberta, Rumeysa contará a sua história e aprenderá junto com outras mulheres que detêm recordes do Livro Guiness.

programme.title: Andrés Iniesta, O Herói Inesperado
programme.desc: Esta é a história de uma pessoa normal que faz coisas extraordinárias. Alguém que persegue e conquista triunfos cuidando dos pequenos detalhes, porque estes são, afinal, os que fazem dele um futebolista diferente. Todos conhecemos Iniesta, o mágico da bola que conquistou dois triples campeonatos com o Barça e levantou a Copa do Mundo com a seleção espanhola. E sim, é claro que conhecemos os seus grandes momentos desportivos. Mas quem está por trás dessa estrela mundial do desporto?

programme.title: HairStyle, The Talent Show -Episódios 1 - 2
programme.desc: No primeiro episódio, para se apresentarem aos jurados, os participantes usam a sua capacidade de engenho para criar um visual livre e solto. O único limite é a sua capacidade criativa. Também serão avaliados quanto a cinco técnicas de cabeleireiro essenciais; o último classificado será eliminado. A celebridade televisiva e influencer de moda Tina Leung irá visitar o salão para revelar a sua rotina de cuidado capilar e oferecer algumas dicas valiosas.

programme.title: Episódios 5-6
programme.desc: Match Point | Noite Europeia

programme.title: Gigantes - Lendas do sumo do Hawaii
programme.desc: Acompanhamos as vidas épicas das lendas do sumo que transcenderam as suas origens humildes no Havai para se tornarem nos primeiros estrangeiros a ascender aos patamares mais elevados do sumo.

programme.title: Ona Carbonell: Começar de novo
programme.desc: Em agosto de 2020, a nadadora artística olímpica Ona Carbonell tornou-se mãe, uma experiência que mudou de imediato a sua vida. Ao mesmo tempo, Ona embarcou num plano ambicioso para competir nos Jogos Olímpicos de Tóquio. O documentário acompanha Ona durante estes 11 meses intensos, em que terá de forçar os seus limites a um grau extraordinário, tanto física como emocionalmente. Acompanhamos Ona de perto, partilhando as suas rotinas e desafios diários, desde a amamentação aos momentos de brincadeira com o bebé Kai, passando pelas sessões de treino intenso com a Seleção Nacional Espanhola.

programme.title: Campeãs
programme.desc: A vencedora de três medalhas olímpicas e Treinadora Feminina do Ano de 2012 da FIFA Pia Sundhage conta-nos como se sentiu quando foi convocada pela primeira vez pela seleção nacional feminina sueca. Pia acredita que o futebol lhe ofereceu um modo de vida. Pia conversa com Stina Blackstenius, vencedora de uma medalha de bronze na Copa do Mundo Feminina da FIFA e vencedora de duas medalhas de prata em Jogos Olímpicos, e com Molly Johansson, ambas jogadoras do BK Häcken. Stina conversa com as duas jogadoras sobre o que sentiu quando participou nos Jogos Olímpicos, e como jogar em França a tornou mais forte, enquanto Molly revela as suas metas para o futuro.

programme.title: Discovering Canary Islands - T2: Lanzarote | Fuerteventura | Gran Canaria
programme.desc: A aventura começa em Lanzarote, no espetacular Charco de la Novia, onde uma prova aquática individual emocionante determinará a formação de duas equipas de 4 concorrentes: a equipa azul e a equipa amarela. Para além disso, a prova dará ao vencedor um privilégio que terá de exercer no final do capítulo: trocar um dos membros da sua equipa por um membro da equipa adversária. Contudo, antes disso, as duas equipas irão enfrentar-se em duras provas nos Jameos del Agua, no Charco de San Ginés e no Castillo de San Gabriel, onde entrará também em jogo o Talismã de Magec, que dará imunidade a um dos membros da equipa vencedora.

programme.title: 265 Days Without Waves (265 dias sem ondas)
programme.desc: Uma história única e extraordinária sobre a criação por um grupo de surfistas locais de uma comunidade e cultura de surf apesar das limitações, numa costa que mal chega aos 100 dias de ondas por ano. Através das personagens, exploramos a evolução do surf bem como a exponencial mudança socioeconómica de Barcelona e arredores, da década de 1960 até à atualidade. Entre os protagonistas aventureiros e dedicados, conhecemos os pioneiros que nadaram contra a maré e a nova geração que vive e respira o surf de uma forma completamente diferente. Frustração, espera e desespero combinam-se em igual medida com entusiasmo, perseverança e humor.

programme.title: HairStyle, The Talent Show -Episódios 1 - 2
programme.desc: No primeiro episódio, para se apresentarem aos jurados, os participantes usam a sua capacidade de engenho para criar um visual livre e solto. O único limite é a sua capacidade criativa. Também serão avaliados quanto a cinco técnicas de cabeleireiro essenciais; o último classificado será eliminado. A celebridade televisiva e influencer de moda Tina Leung irá visitar o salão para revelar a sua rotina de cuidado capilar e oferecer algumas dicas valiosas.

programme.title: We All Play
programme.desc: “WE ALL PLAY” é um projeto que explora a realidade da comunidade LGBTQIA+ no mundo do desporto. Através de uma viagem à volta do mundo, este documentário inspirador apresenta-nos atletas de elite extraordinários que, muitas vezes pela primeira vez, partilham as suas experiências pessoais e profissionais. Os seus testemunhos revelam visões diferentes e opiniões profundas sobre os triunfos e os desafios diários enfrentados por estes atletas. Dando ênfase à importância da inclusão e da aceitação, o documentário evidencia como o desporto pode constituir um espaço para a diversidade e o respeito, promovendo uma mudança positiva em todas as áreas do desporto e para além dele.

programme.title: Brother's Body
programme.desc: Quando decide (voltar a) mergulhar no mundo do culturismo, David Nicolas Parel ambiciona seguir nas pisadas do seu irmão mais novo e treinar para o Arnold Classic – uma competição que deve o nome ao célebre ator e político austríaco-americano.

programme.title: River Memories
programme.desc: Uma comunidade está prestes a desaparecer. Os habitantes de Platz, um enorme bairro de lata em Turim, Itália, defrontam-se com um plano imposto pelo governo e veem-se ameaçados pelo despejo. Este filme documenta os últimos meses do bairro.

programme.title: Break Through
programme.desc: Uma peça encenada por estudantes de teatro torna-se num espetáculo subversivo em prol dos direitos LGBT.

programme.title: Campeãs
programme.desc: Carmen Arce, "Kubalita", guarda-redes da primeira seleção nacional feminina espanhola, parte de Valencia para Barcelona para conhecer Alexia Putellas, vencedora da Liga dos Campeões da UEFA e da Supertaça Europeia, e Viktoria Adrianova, ambas jogadoras do FC Barcelona. Antes do encontro, Alexia confessa não ser tão impaciente como outrora, Viky emociona-se ao recordar a sua lesão e Kubalita afirma que elas não se esconderam, apesar de os políticos e os meios de comunicação terem subestimado a sua atividade. Assim que se reuniram, trocaram impressões sobre o momento atual do futebol feminino.

programme.title: Barcelona: Surf Destination
programme.desc: Em "Barcelona: Surf Destination", Ítalo Ferreira, o primeiro campeão olímpico de surf, aceita o convite do seu amigo Alex Vilalta e viaja para Barcelona para explorar a costa catalã e conhecer a comunidade de surfistas que mantém o espírito do surf aceso neste reduto mediterrâneo. Neste documentário de aventuras repletas de sol, somos convidados a partir numas férias com amigos que se reúnem para tagarelar e entregar-se àquilo que os apaixona: o surf.

programme.title: HairStyle, The Talent Show -Episódios 5 - 6
programme.desc: Nem sempre é fácil agradar os clientes, mas os participantes não podem desiludir. Irão indicar os seus modelos e descobrir o que querem, para concretizarem os seus desejos na máxima medida possível. A atriz, modelo e celebridade televisiva e Christine Quinn irá visitar o salão e partilhar algumas das suas dicas de cuidados capilares com os participantes. No segundo desafio, os participantes irão trabalhar com modelos e dedicar-se à pintura de cabelo. Cada visual pode destacar a beleza natural da modelo, ao mesmo tempo que alimenta os seus cabelos, dado que as tintas podem ser prejudiciais.

programme.title: Bojan, por trás do sorriso
programme.desc: Depois de retirar-se dos relvados aos 32 anos, Bojan Krkic decide contar a sua história. Através de uma conversa com o psicanalista que o tratou quando da sua estreia com o FC Barcelona aos 16 anos, o documentário explora as dificuldades enfrentadas por um talento precoce e sensível no mundo cruel do futebol. Jogadores que testemunharam a sua carreira de perto, tais como Thierry Henry, Andrés Iniesta e Zlatan Ibrahimovic, partilham o seu ponto de vista sobre Bojan, o futebolista, e Bojan, a pessoa, e refletem sobre a pressão, saúde mental e gestão de expetativas.

programme.title: A minha Decisão, por Andrés Iniesta
programme.desc: "São poucas as pessoas que sabem o que aconteceu quando me lesionei. Poucas sabem que tive de tomar uma decisão de enorme importância. Valia a pena continuar a jogar, ou estava na altura de parar?" Um documentário revelador sobre o lendário médio, Andrés Iniesta, quando enfrenta uma decisão crucial após uma lesão que ameaça a sua carreira. A história de um amor de longa data pelo futebol, sob a ameaça de uma situação cruel e inevitável.

programme.title: The Peddler
programme.desc: Daniel Burmeister, um cinéfilo de barbas, viaja de terra em terra a realizar filmes de muito baixo orçamento com os autóctones, e em tempo recorde!

programme.title: Discovering Canary Islands - Episódio 5-6
programme.desc: Episódio 5 - La Palma | Episódio 6 - El Hierro and La Gomera

programme.title: Finding Hope Home
programme.desc: Os cineastas Wambui Ndegwa e Cole Lewis tornam a realidade queniana visível através da história de uma família que começou a adotar crianças sem-abrigo no Nairobi em 1996.

programme.title: SEVE - Artista, Lutador, Lenda
programme.desc: Seve continua a ser uma lenda, um campeão multi-major, o homem responsável por fazer da moderna Ryder Cup um grande acontecimento. A sua paixão pelo golfe era tal que ainda criança esgueirava no campo para jogar à noite, futuramente faria o mesmo num esforço "para encontrar a magia". A sua história é contada por membros da sua família e do seu círculo interno, por outros grandes desportistas e através do material recentemente descoberto. É um conto hipnotizante de talento, crença e bravura - a história da vida de Seve… e da sua morte.

programme.title: Break Point: a Davis Cup Story
programme.desc: Liderada por Rafa Nadal, a seleção espanhola era a favorita deste ano até sofrer um sério revés. O jogador número dois da equipa, Roberto Bautista, teve de deixar a disputa para voltar à sua cidade natal e ficar ao lado do pai nas últimas horas da sua vida. Sem o Bautista, Nadal e Feliciano López conseguiram heroicamente levar a equipa à final. Mas então veio a notícia que emocionou os fãs de ténis em todo o mundo: Bautista, após o funeral do seu pai, está de volta à competição e pronto para jogar. Unidos mais uma vez, os espanhóis lutam pela vitória na grande final, onde algo muito além do ténis está em jogo.

programme.title: Karate-do: O Caminho de Sandra Sánchez
programme.desc: Não é um dragão, mas parece no dojo. Eis Sandra Sánchez, uma das maiores figuras do karate de sempre. Esta é a história do seu percurso único. Dos seus feitos. Uma história complicada que inclui a prática do karate em criança, uma relação abusiva na vida adulta e um penúltimo ano de carreira inacreditável onde que bateu recordes ao competir nos três mais prestigiosos campeonatos de karate – e vencê-los. O caminho até ao sucesso nunca é fácil, mas nos Jogos Olímpicos de Tóquio, Sandra lutou por e contra muitas dificuldades para conquistar um lugar nos anais da história.

programme.title: Discovering Canary Islands - Episódio 1-2

programme.title: Make Up Stars - T1: Natureza - E o vencedor é...

Contarão com a assistência dos antigos concorrentes e receberão a visita de umas das mais influentes maquilhadoras das redes sociais e uma verdadeira especialista em pintura corporal: Nuria Adraos. A jovem artista dará conselhos aos concorrentes, enquanto estes lutam por um lugar na final.

programme.title: A is for Apple
programme.sub-title: S02 : E03 Kaffir Lime and Kohlrabi
programme.desc: Chef Robert Jewell has a challenge on his hands after picking the letter “K.” He decides to use ingredients kaffir lime and kohlrabi. First, Robert re-invents the ordinary shrimp skewer, using lemongrass as the skewer (yes, the skewer!). He brings the flavour to the next level with zesty kaffir lime. Using the leaves of the kaffir lime with fresh herbs, Robert makes a dipping sauce for the skewer. Next, Robert fries up salty peameal bacon in one pan and sautés earthy kohlrabi with leeks, potato, and garlic in another. He brings the ingredients together into a single skillet, adding eggs and baking it into a hearty frittata. For his final dish, Robert uses both kaffir lime and kohlrabi in...

programme.title: One BIG Recipe
programme.desc: Spring is in the air for this multi-course dinner One Big Recipe with engaging Chef Kimberly Lallouz. First up, it's Scallop Crudo, and it's peachy! Literally! Lamb Shanks braised with olives and sun-dried tomatoes are next, as an appetizer ragout, lovingly stuffed into pillowy, perfect mini-Yorkshire Puddings. Next, verdant spears of asparagus appear, topped with creamy, crunchy, soft-cooked egg Sauce Gribiche. Halibut is the main event, pan-roasted steaks are served over king trumpet Dill Pesto Mushrooms and finished with many melty coins of punchy Pink Peppercorn Compound Butter. The entire dinner is laid out in the signature One Big Recipe format, easy to follow, easy to make and...

programme.title: A is for Apple
programme.desc: "A" is on the menu and Chef Robert Jewell takes on this meal challenge with apricots and avocados. First up, Robert cooks a spicy roasted quail and drizzles it with some sweet apricot and calvados sauce. Next, is a meal best served cold! Robert slices up sushi-grade tuna and transforms it into a flavourful tartare, brought to life by rich avocado and refreshing lime. On the side, he adds crusty crostini with savoury soy sauce and sesame oil, the perfect complement for this meltin- your-mouth meal. For his final dish, Robert combines apricots and avocados for an unbelievably tasty dish.

programme.title: A is for Apple
programme.desc: Host Theresa Visintin picks the letter “D” in this challenge and combines two very different ingredients – dill and duck! But that’s no big dill for Theresa. For her first dish, Theresa uses dill seeds and weed to make a hearty, creamy dill pickle soup. She adds chicken broth and potatoes as her base but makes the soup extra smooth with some sour cream. She tops the soup with dill pickles to add a delightful crunch. Next, Theresa takes duck, a classic French ingredient, and gives it a French Canadian twist – duck tourtière. Using the duck fat to fry up some veggies, she adds red wine to her chicken stock and simmers the meat. Then, Theresa fills a pie crust with this delightful duck...
